scenarios.title: Full Main Residence Exemption
scenarios.description: Sarah purchases her first home and lives in it continuously from purchase until sale. Full main residence exemption applies.

properties.notes: sold - Full main residence exemption applies. Lived in property entire ownership period.

scenarios.userQuery: I lived in my home for the entire time I owned it. What is my CGT liability on sale?

scenarios.title: 6-Year Absence Rule (Within Limit)
scenarios.description: Michael purchases a home, lives in it for 4 years, then moves interstate for work and rents out the property for 5 years. Six-year rule applies - full exemption.

properties.notes: sold - Six-year absence rule applies. Rented for 5 years while working interstate. Full exemption.

scenarios.userQuery: I moved interstate for work and rented my home for 5 years before selling. What is my CGT liability?

scenarios.title: 6-Year Absence Rule (Exceeded)
scenarios.description: Property owner lived in for 2 years, then rented out for over 10 years (exceeding the 6-year rule). Partial exemption applies based on time as main residence.

properties.address: 15 Ocean View Drive, Byron Bay NSW 2481
properties.notes: sold - lived in 2 years, rented 10+ years, exceeds six-year rule

scenarios.userQuery: I lived in this property for 2 years, then moved overseas and rented it out for over 10 years before selling. Please calculate my CGT liability.

scenarios.title: Rental First, Then Main Residence
scenarios.description: Emma purchases an investment property and rents it immediately. After 3 years, she moves in. Six-year rule does NOT apply - only main residence period is exempt.

scenario_info.name: Rental First, Then Main Residence (First Use to Produce Income)

properties.notes: sold - Investment property converted to main residence. Partial exemption for main residence period only.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought an investment property, rented it for 3 years, then moved in for 5 years before selling. What CGT do I owe?

scenarios.title: Moving Between Residences
scenarios.description: David owns his main residence and purchases a new home. He moves in while still owning the old one (5.5 month overlap). Both properties treated as main residence under s118.140.

scenario_info.name: Moving Between Main Residences (6-Month Overlap Rule)

properties.notes: sold - Original main residence sold within 6-month overlap period. Full exemption under s118.140.
ppr - Current main residence. Overlap with Property 1 sale within 6-month window.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought a new home and moved in before selling my old home. The overlap was about 5.5 months. What CGT do I owe?

scenarios.title: Full Main Residence (Variant B)
scenarios.description: I lived in my home for the entire time I owned it. What is my CGT liability on sale?

properties.notes: sold - Full main residence exemption applies. Lived in property entire ownership period.

scenarios.userQuery: I lived in my home for the entire time I owned it. What is my CGT liability on sale?

scenarios.title: 6-Year Rule Within (Variant B)
scenarios.description: I moved to Melbourne for work and rented my Gold Coast home for about 5.5 years before selling. What is my CGT liability?

properties.notes: sold - Six-year absence rule applies. Rented for 5.67 years while working in Melbourne. Full exemption.

scenarios.userQuery: I moved to Melbourne for work and rented my Gold Coast home for about 5.5 years before selling. What is my CGT liability?

scenarios.title: 6-Year Rule Exceeded (Variant B)
scenarios.description: I rented my Sydney home for over 8 years while working in Singapore. How much CGT do I owe now that I've sold?

properties.address: 42 Harbour View Road, McMahons Point NSW 2060
properties.notes: sold - Six-year rule exceeded. Rented for 8.67 years while in Singapore. Partial exemption applies. First use to produce income rule triggered.

scenarios.userQuery: I rented my Sydney home for over 8 years while working in Singapore. How much CGT do I owe now that I've sold?

scenarios.title: Rental First (Variant B)
scenarios.description: I bought an investment property, rented it for 4 years, then moved in for 6 years before selling. What CGT do I owe?

properties.notes: sold - Investment property converted to main residence. Partial exemption for main residence period only.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought an investment property, rented it for 4 years, then moved in for 6 years before selling. What CGT do I owe?

scenarios.title: Moving Between Residences (Variant B)
scenarios.description: I bought a new home and moved in before selling my old home. The overlap was about 4.5 months. What CGT do I owe?

properties.notes: sold - Original main residence sold within 6-month overlap period. Full exemption under s118.140.
ppr - Current main residence. Overlap with Property 1 sale within 6-month window.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought a new home and moved in before selling my old home. The overlap was about 4.5 months. What CGT do I owe?

scenarios.title: Multiple Absence Periods
scenarios.description: Ian owns a Sydney home and is posted to different cities for work over 30 years. He rents out Sydney during absences, buys/sells other properties, but never claims MRE on them. The combined rental periods exceed 6 years.

scenario_info.name: Multiple Absence Periods (ATO Example 80)
applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule (partial - combined rental exceeds 6 years)
Multiple absence periods are combined for the 6-year test
Can choose to treat Sydney as MR since no other property claimed as MR
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies

properties.notes: Complex scenario with multiple rental periods totaling 7 years. First 6 years exempt under s118.145, remaining 1 year (365 days) is taxable.
Brisbane property - MRE not claimed to preserve Sydney six-year rule
Melbourne property - MRE not claimed to preserve Sydney six-year rule

scenarios.userQuery: I owned my Sydney home for 30 years but rented it out during two work relocations totaling 7 years. I also bought and sold properties in Brisbane and Melbourne but never claimed MRE on them. What is my CGT position?

scenarios.title: Two Properties - Strategic MRE Choice
scenarios.description: David owns two properties and must strategically choose which one to claim the main residence exemption on. He lived in a beach house first, then moved to a city apartment. The beach house was rented for exactly 6 years.

scenario_info.name: Two Properties with Strategic MRE Decision

expected_result.notes: If beach house MRE claimed, it gets full exemption (6-year rule). City apartment would be partially taxable.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule applies to beach house (rental = 6 years exactly)
Can only claim ONE property as main residence at any time
Strategic choice: Claim MRE on property with larger gain
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies to taxable portions

properties.notes: Beach house - rented for exactly 6 years. If MRE claimed here, six-year rule provides full exemption.
City apartment - if beach house gets MRE, this property is fully taxable as investment

scenarios.userQuery: I owned a beach house and a city apartment. I lived in the beach house first, then moved to the apartment and rented the beach house for 6 years. Which property should I claim the main residence exemption on?

scenarios.title: Inherited Property with Rental
scenarios.description: Emma inherits her mother's home (which was mum's main residence) and then rents it out before selling more than 2 years after the date of death.

scenario_info.name: Inherited Property Then Rented

expected_result.notes: Since sold more than 2 years after death and Emma never lived there, no MRE applies for Emma's period.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.195: 2-year disposal rule NOT met (sold 4+ years after death)
Cost base = Market value at date of death ($780,000)
Emma never established property as her main residence
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies (inherited acquisition date)

properties.notes: Inherited property. Mother's MRE would have applied if sold within 2 years. Since sold after 4 years and rented entire time, no MRE for Emma.

scenarios.userQuery: I inherited my mother's home in 2020. She lived there her whole life. I rented it out and sold it in 2024. What is my CGT liability?

scenarios.title: Investment  Main Residence  Rental
scenarios.description: Michael buys an investment property, later moves in as main residence, then moves out and rents again. The six-year rule does NOT apply because property was rented before becoming main residence.

scenario_info.name: Complex Pattern: Rental-PPR-Rental

expected_result.notes: Six-year rule unavailable. Only actual residence period exempt.

applicable_rules: Six-year rule (s118.145) does NOT apply - property was investment BEFORE main residence
ITAA97 s118.185: Partial main residence exemption for actual residence period only
Original cost base used (not market value reset)
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies

properties.address: Unit 12/88 Boundary Street, West End QLD 4101
properties.notes: Property was rented BEFORE becoming main residence. Six-year rule cannot apply. Only the 1,144 days of actual residence (15 Jul 2017 to 1 Sep 2020) are exempt.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought a unit as an investment, rented it for 3.5 years, then moved in for 3 years, then moved out and rented again for 4 years before selling. What is my CGT liability?

scenarios.title: 6-Month Overlap Rule Exceeded
scenarios.description: Jennifer buys a new home before selling her old one, but takes 8.5 months to sell the old home, exceeding the 6-month overlap allowance by 74 days.

scenario_info.name: Moving Between Homes - Overlap Exceeded

expected_result.notes: 74 days of overlap period taxable on one property

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.140: 6-month overlap rule
Overlap of 257 days exceeds 183-day limit by 74 days
Must choose which property loses exemption for excess period
Old home taxable for 74 days (smallest proportion)
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies

properties.notes: Old home - overlap period of 257 days (8.5 months) exceeds 6-month limit. 74 days are taxable.
New home - keeping as main residence. Not being sold.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought a new home in February 2024 and moved in immediately, but didn't sell my old home until October 2024. The overlap was about 8.5 months. What is my CGT position on the old home?

scenarios.title: Construction & 4-Year Building Rule
scenarios.description: Robert buys vacant land and builds his dream home. Construction takes 2.6 years. The 4-year construction rule allows the land to be treated as main residence from purchase.

scenario_info.name: 4-Year Construction Rule Application
applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.150: 4-year construction rule applies
Construction period (2.6 years) is within 4-year limit
Land treated as main residence from acquisition date
Moved in as soon as practicable after completion
Full main residence exemption applies

properties.notes: 4-year construction rule applies. Construction took 2.6 years (within 4-year limit). Full MRE available.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought vacant land in 2020, built a home which was completed in late 2022, moved in January 2023, and sold in 2024. Do I qualify for the main residence exemption?

scenarios.title: Partial Use - Airbnb Room Rental
scenarios.description: Sophie lives in her home but rents out a spare room on Airbnb for 5 years. The interest deductibility test applies, requiring floor area apportionment.

scenario_info.name: Home with Airbnb Room Rental

expected_result.notes: Floor area and time apportionment required

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.190: Interest deductibility test applies
Exclusive rented area: 18/180 sqm = 10%
Shared areas: (45/180) x 50% = 12.5%
Total income-producing: 22.5%
Time factor: 1,826/3,059 days = 59.7%

properties.notes: Partial rental (Airbnb room) while living in property. Floor area apportionment: 22.5% income-producing. Rental period: 5 years of 8.4 year ownership.

scenarios.userQuery: I lived in my home for 8 years but rented out a spare room on Airbnb for 5 of those years. The room was 18sqm and guests shared 45sqm of common areas. Total home is 180sqm. What is my CGT liability?

scenarios.title: Couple with Separate Properties
scenarios.description: Alex and Sam each own a home before they get married. After cohabitation, they can only claim one property as main residence. Alex's property becomes partially taxable.

scenario_info.name: Couple with Separate Properties Before Marriage

expected_result.notes: From cohabitation date, couple must choose ONE main residence

applicable_rules: Couples can only claim ONE main residence at any time
From cohabitation (1 Mar 2020), must choose which property is MR
Alex's property: MR for 1,705 days before cohabitation
Alex's property: NOT MR for 1,660 days after cohabitation
Total ownership: 3,365 days
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies

properties.notes: Alex's property before marriage. From cohabitation, couple claimed Sam's property as MR, so six-year rule cannot apply here.
Sam's property - continues as couple's main residence after marriage. Not being sold.

scenarios.userQuery: Alex and Sam each owned a home before getting together. When Alex moved in with Sam in March 2020, they chose Sam's place as their main residence. Alex then rented out and sold the Bulimba property. What is the CGT on Alex's property?

scenarios.title: Foreign Resident Period Impact
scenarios.description: Lisa is an Australian resident who moves to Singapore for work for 4 years, becoming a foreign resident for tax purposes. She rents her Australian home, then returns before selling.

scenario_info.name: Australian Who Moves Overseas Then Returns

expected_result.notes: Six-year rule applies. Since Lisa returned before selling, she is Australian resident at sale and can claim MRE.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule applies (rental = 4 years < 6 years)
Lisa was foreign resident for 4 years but RETURNED before sale
Since Australian resident at time of sale, MRE available
CGT discount would be reduced for foreign resident period if gain was taxable
Full MRE means no CGT payable regardless

properties.notes: Owner was foreign resident from July 2018 to June 2022 (4 years). Returned to Australia before selling, so MRE available. Six-year rule applies (4 years rental < 6 years).

scenarios.userQuery: I moved to Singapore for work in 2018 and rented out my Australian home for 4 years. I returned to Australia in 2022 and sold in 2024. What is my CGT position?

scenarios.title: Three Property Portfolio
scenarios.description: Investment portfolio with three properties sold in the same financial year. Each property has different CGT treatment: family home (full MRE), investment unit (no exemption), holiday house (no exemption, mixed use).

scenario_info.name: Multiple Properties with Different CGT Treatments
applicable_rules: Property A: Full MRE - main residence entire period
Property B: No exemption - pure investment from day one
Property C: No exemption - holiday house with occasional rental
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies to B and C
Capital gains aggregated for the financial year

properties.notes: Family home - main residence entire ownership period. Full MRE applies. Net capital gain: $0

properties.address: Unit 8/120 Brunswick Street, Fortitude Valley QLD 4006
properties.notes: Investment unit - rented from day one, never lived in. No MRE. Capital gain: $115,575. After 50% discount: $57,788
Holiday house - not main residence, mixed personal/rental use. No MRE. Capital gain: $288,600. After 50% discount: $144,300

scenarios.userQuery: I'm selling three properties in the same year: my family home that I've lived in for 14 years, an investment unit I've had for 8 years, and a holiday house in Noosa that I've had for 6 years. What's my total CGT?

scenarios.title: Aged Care - Indefinite Absence
scenarios.description: Margaret purchases her home and lives in it for 20 years before entering permanent aged care. She leaves the property vacant (not rented) for 7 years while in aged care before selling. Because the property was not used to produce income during her absence, she can treat it as her main residence indefinitely under s118.145.

scenario_info.name: Aged Care Entry with Indefinite Absence
applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Indefinite absence rule applies (property not income producing)
Property can be treated as main residence indefinitely when not rented
No limit on how long the property can be vacant
Full exemption applies regardless of 7+ years in aged care

properties.notes: Full main residence exemption. Property was vacant (not rented) during aged care. Under s118.145, property continues to be treated as main residence indefinitely when not producing income.

scenarios.userQuery: I moved into aged care 7 years ago and left my home vacant the entire time. I never rented it out. Now I'm selling it. What is my CGT liability?

scenarios.title: Delayed Move-In (Work Assignment)
scenarios.description: Anthony purchases a home but cannot move in immediately due to a work assignment overseas that was arranged before the purchase. He moves in 8 months after purchase when his assignment ends. Because the delay was due to unforeseen work circumstances, the dwelling is treated as his main residence from the acquisition date.

scenario_info.name: Delayed Move-In Due to Work Assignment
applicable_rules: ATO guidance on delayed move-in: Valid exceptions include illness or work-related travel
Delay of 8 months accepted due to pre-arranged overseas work assignment
Moved in as soon as practicable (5 days after assignment ended)
Property not rented during delay = full exemption from acquisition date
Note: Renting during delay would NOT qualify for this exception

properties.notes: Full main residence exemption. Delayed move-in exception applies due to pre-arranged overseas work assignment. Property treated as main residence from acquisition date.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought my home but couldn't move in for 8 months because I was overseas on a work assignment that was arranged before the purchase. I moved in as soon as I returned. What's my CGT situation?

scenarios.title: Multiple 6-Year Periods Reset
scenarios.description: Rebecca purchases a home, lives in it for 5 years, rents it out for 4 years while working overseas, moves back in for 2 years, then rents it again for 5 years before selling. Because she genuinely moved back in and re-established the property as her main residence, she is entitled to a new 6-year period for the second rental. The full main residence exemption applies.

scenario_info.name: Multiple Six-Year Periods Reset
applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule can be reset
When owner genuinely moves back in and re-establishes main residence, a new 6-year period starts
9 years total rental split: 4 years + 5 years = both within respective 6-year limits
Key: Must genuinely re-establish main residence (not just a brief visit)

properties.notes: Full main residence exemption. First rental (4 years) covered by first 6-year period. Genuine move-back reset the clock. Second rental (5 years) covered by new 6-year period.

scenarios.userQuery: I rented my home for 4 years, moved back in for 2 years, then rented it again for 5 years before selling. That's 9 years of rental total. Is my six-year rule exceeded?

scenarios.title: Deceased Estate (Within 2 Years)
scenarios.description: William's mother passes away and leaves him her home, which was her main residence. William sells the property within 2 years of her death. Because the property was the deceased's main residence and was sold within 2 years, William is entitled to a full CGT exemption under the deceased estate provisions.

scenario_info.name: Deceased Estate Sold Within Two Years
applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.195: 2-year disposal rule
Property was deceased's main residence at time of death
Sold within 2 years = Full exemption (regardless of whether beneficiary lived there)
William did not need to move in to claim exemption
Note: If sold after 2 years, partial exemption may apply

properties.notes: Full CGT exemption under 2-year disposal rule. Property was mother's main residence and sold within 2 years of death (688 days). William never lived there but still qualifies for full exemption.

scenarios.userQuery: I inherited my mother's home when she passed away in March 2023. It was her main residence. I never lived there but I'm selling it now in February 2025. What's my CGT liability?

scenarios.title: Beneficiary Moves Into Inherited Property
scenarios.description: Sarah inherits her father's investment property (which was NOT his main residence). She moves into the property as her main residence for 4 years before selling. Because the property was not the deceased's main residence, Sarah cannot use the 2-year rule. However, she can claim the main residence exemption for the period she lived there.

scenario_info.name: Beneficiary Moves Into Inherited Property

expected_result.notes: Small taxable portion due to 16-day delay before moving in. After 50% discount.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.195: 2-year rule NOT applicable (property was NOT deceased's main residence)
Sarah inherits father's cost base and acquisition date
ITAA97 s118.185: Partial main residence exemption for period Sarah lived there
Small taxable portion due to 16-day delay before moving in
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies

properties.notes: Partial main residence exemption (98.98%). 2-year rule does NOT apply because property was father's investment, not his main residence. Sarah inherits father's cost base. Only the 16-day vacant period before Sarah moved in is taxable.

scenarios.userQuery: I inherited my father's investment property in 2020 - he never lived there, it was always rented. I moved in and made it my main residence for 4 years. What's my CGT when I sell?

scenarios.title: Pre-CGT with Major Improvements
scenarios.description: George purchased a property in 1982 (before CGT commenced on 20 September 1985). In 2015, he undertook a major renovation costing $250,000. He sells the property in 2024. While the original property is exempt as a pre-CGT asset, the major capital improvement is a separate CGT asset. However, since it was his main residence, both are exempt.

scenario_info.name: Pre-CGT Property with Major Post-CGT Improvements

expected_result.notes: Pre-CGT property exempt. Major improvement also exempt under main residence exemption.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s149.10: Pre-CGT assets (acquired before 20 September 1985) exempt
ITAA97 s108.70: Major capital improvements are separate CGT assets
Major improvement threshold 2024-25: >5% of proceeds AND >$182,665
ITAA97 s118.110: Main residence exemption extends to improvements used as part of home
Note: If property was NOT main residence, improvement would be taxable

properties.notes: Full exemption. Original property is pre-CGT (exempt). Major renovation ($250,000 > $182,665 threshold and > 5% of sale) is technically a separate CGT asset, but is also exempt because property was main residence for entire ownership.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought my home in 1982 before CGT started. I did a major $250,000 renovation in 2015. Now I'm selling for $680,000. Is any part taxable?

scenarios.title: Large Rural Property (>2 Hectares)
scenarios.description: Patricia owns a 5-hectare rural property where she has lived for 15 years. The main residence exemption only applies to the dwelling and up to 2 hectares of adjacent land used for private purposes. She must choose which 2 hectares to include, with the remaining 3 hectares subject to CGT.

scenario_info.name: Large Rural Property Exceeding Two Hectares

expected_result.notes: After 50% CGT discount. Only dwelling + 2ha exempt, remaining 3ha taxable.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.120: Main residence exemption includes adjacent land up to 2 hectares
Land must be used mainly for private and domestic purposes
ATO TD 1999/67: Client can choose which 2 hectares are included
Remaining land (3 hectares) is a separate CGT asset
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies to taxable portion

properties.notes: Partial exemption. Main residence exemption covers dwelling + 2 hectares (60% = $720,000). Remaining 3 hectares ($480,000) is taxable. Capital gain on taxable portion: $291,320. After 50% discount: $145,660.

scenarios.userQuery: I've lived on my 5 hectare rural property for 15 years. I know there's a 2 hectare limit on the main residence exemption. How much CGT will I pay when I sell?

scenarios.title: Granny Flat Arrangement
scenarios.description: Helen transfers her home to her daughter Isabella in exchange for a granny flat right (right to live in the property for life). Since 1 July 2021, CGT does not apply when creating a granny flat arrangement. Helen's main residence exemption covers the transfer, and Isabella has no CGT liability for granting the granny flat right.

scenario_info.name: Granny Flat Arrangement

expected_result.notes: Both parties exempt - Helen (MRE + granny flat exemption), Isabella (MRE on sale)

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.80: Granny flat arrangements exempt from CGT (from 1 July 2021)
Helen: MRE applies to transfer + Granny flat CGT exemption
Isabella: No CGT on granting life interest + MRE on eventual sale
Granny flat must be: Written, non-commercial, provide life interest
Transfer for market value = Isabella's cost base for future CGT

properties.notes: Full exemption for all parties. Helen's transfer exempt under MRE + granny flat arrangement (s118.80). Isabella's sale exempt under MRE (lived there as main residence since transfer). Granny flat exemption applies from 1 July 2021.

scenarios.userQuery: My mother transferred her house to me in 2022 in exchange for a granny flat arrangement where she could live there for life. She recently passed away and I'm selling. What are the CGT implications?

scenarios.title: Relationship Breakdown Rollover
scenarios.description: Mark and Linda divorce after 12 years of marriage. Their family home is transferred to Linda as part of the property settlement. Under the relationship breakdown rollover provisions, Mark disregards any capital gain on the transfer. Linda inherits Mark's cost base and acquisition date.

scenario_info.name: Relationship Breakdown Property Transfer

expected_result.notes: Mark's transfer exempt under rollover. Linda's sale exempt under MRE.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s126.5: Relationship breakdown CGT rollover
Transfer must be due to court order, BFA, or award
Mark's gain/loss disregarded on transfer
Linda inherits Mark's cost base AND acquisition date
ITAA97 s118.110: Main residence exemption applies to Linda's sale
Key: Linda's ownership period includes Mark's original purchase date

properties.notes: Full exemption. Mark's transfer to Linda exempt under relationship breakdown rollover (s126.5). Linda inherits Mark's cost base and acquisition date. Linda's sale exempt under MRE as property was her main residence for entire period (including Mark's original ownership).

scenarios.userQuery: My ex-husband transferred his share of our family home to me as part of our divorce settlement. I've now sold it. What are the CGT implications for both of us?

scenarios.title: Home Office Business Use
scenarios.description: Daniel works from home and has used 15% of his home exclusively for his photography business for the past 6 years. When he sells the property, the business-use portion is not eligible for the full main residence exemption under the interest deductibility test.

scenario_info.name: Home Office Business Use

expected_result.notes: After 50% CGT discount. 11.67% taxable (15% floor area x 77.79% time).

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.190: Interest deductibility test
Part of home used for income-producing purposes (business)
Taxable proportion = Floor area % x Time proportion
Business use of 15% for 77.79% of ownership = 11.67% taxable
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies to taxable portion
Note: Different from Airbnb room rental - this is exclusive business use

properties.notes: Partial exemption (88.33%). Business use of 15% floor area for 7 years (77.79% of 9-year ownership). Taxable portion = 15% x 77.79% = 11.67%. Capital gain $223,000. Taxable: $26,024. After 50% discount: $13,012.

scenarios.userQuery: I've used 15% of my home exclusively for my photography business for the past 7 years. I've claimed deductions for that portion. Now I'm selling. What's my CGT position?

scenarios.title: Foreign Resident Life Event
scenarios.description: Jessica moved to the UK in 2019 and became a foreign resident for tax purposes. In 2023, her husband passed away. Under the life event exception, she has 6 years from the date of his death to sell her Australian main residence and claim the main residence exemption, despite being a foreign resident.

scenario_info.name: Foreign Resident Life Event Exception

expected_result.notes: Life event exception + six-year rule = full exemption despite foreign residency

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.110: Foreign residents cannot claim MRE (since 1 July 2020)
Exception: Life event within 6 years - death of spouse, child under 18, or terminal illness
ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule (rental 5.67 years < 6 years)
Jessica can claim MRE despite being foreign resident due to husband's death
Must sell within 6 years of life event (sold 1.5 years after)

properties.notes: Full exemption. Although Jessica is a foreign resident, the life event exception (husband's death) allows her to claim MRE. Sold within 6 years of life event (1.5 years). Six-year absence rule also satisfied (rental 5.67 years).

scenarios.userQuery: I became a foreign resident in 2019 when I moved to the UK. My husband passed away in 2023. I'm selling my Australian home in 2025. Can I still claim the main residence exemption?

scenarios.title: Pre-9 May 2012 Foreign Residency
scenarios.description: Andrew owned his main residence since 2008 and became a foreign resident from 2015-2020. He returned to Australia and sold in 2024. Because he owned the property before 9 May 2012 and was a resident on that date, special rules apply. The six-year absence rule covers the rental, so full MRE applies.

scenario_info.name: Pre-9 May 2012 Property with Foreign Residency

expected_result.notes: Australian resident at sale + six-year rule = full MRE

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule (rental 5 years < 6 years)
Returned to Australia and sold as resident = Can claim MRE
ITAA97 s115.105: CGT discount reduced for foreign resident periods (post-9 May 2012)
Special rule: Property owned on 9 May 2012 while resident = Pre-9 May portion gets full discount
Since full MRE applies, these discount rules don't affect outcome

properties.notes: Full exemption. Owned property before 9 May 2012 and was Australian resident on that date. Foreign resident period (2015-2020) covered by six-year absence rule (5 years). Returned to Australia before sale = full MRE applies.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought my home in 2008 and lived overseas from 2015-2020 as a foreign resident. I rented it out for those 5 years. I'm back in Australia now and selling. What's my CGT?

scenarios.title: Spouses - Different Main Residences
scenarios.description: Chris and Morgan are married but live in different cities for work. Chris lives in Brisbane and Morgan lives in Sydney. They each nominate their respective dwelling as their main residence. Under s118.170, spouses can claim different main residences, but with limitations on the exemption.

scenario_info.name: Spouses Nominating Different Main Residences

expected_result.notes: After 50% discount. Only 50% exemption during period of different main residences.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.170: Spouses living in different main residences
If spouse owns >50% of nominated dwelling, exemption = 50% for period living apart
Chris owns 100%, so only 50% exemption applies during different MR period
If Chris owned 50% or less, would get 100% exemption on their share
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies

properties.notes: Partial exemption (58.31%). Period 1: Joint main residence (407 days) = 100% exempt. Period 2: Different main residences (2,041 days) = only 50% exempt because Chris owns 100%. Taxable gain after 50% discount: $42,982.
Morgan's Sydney property - nominated as Morgan's main residence from 15 March 2019. Not sold in this scenario.

scenarios.userQuery: My spouse and I live in different cities for work. I own a property in Brisbane and my spouse owns one in Sydney. We each live in our own property. I'm selling the Brisbane property. What's my CGT?

scenarios.title: Vacant Periods During Rental
scenarios.description: Michelle rents her main residence for 8 years with two vacant periods when tenants change. The vacant periods count towards the 6-year limit when the property is available for rent. Total rental period exceeds 6 years, resulting in partial exemption.

scenario_info.name: Vacant Periods During Extended Rental

expected_result.notes: After 50% discount. Vacant periods while available for rent count towards 6-year limit.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule exceeded
Vacant periods while property available for rent count towards 6-year limit
Only genuinely taking property off rental market stops the clock
ITAA97 s118.192: First use to produce income rule
50% CGT discount applies to taxable portion
Rental period (9 years including vacant) exceeds 6 years by 3 years

properties.notes: Partial exemption (66.69%). Total rental period including vacant periods: 9 years. Exceeds 6-year limit by 3 years. Market value at first rental ($340,000) becomes cost base. Taxable gain after 50% discount: $27,481.

scenarios.userQuery: I've rented my home for 8 years but there were two vacant periods between tenants (3 months and 2 months). The property was always available for rent during those times. Does the 6-year rule still apply?

scenarios.title: 4-Year Construction Rule Exceeded
scenarios.description: Brian purchases vacant land and builds his home, but construction takes 5 years due to delays. Because the 4-year construction rule is exceeded, the land can only be treated as his main residence for the 4 years immediately before the completed dwelling became his main residence.

scenario_info.name: Four-Year Construction Rule Exceeded

expected_result.notes: After 50% discount. First year of land ownership not covered by 4-year rule.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.150: 4-year construction rule
If construction exceeds 4 years, MRE only applies for 4 years before completion
Land was not MR for first year (excess beyond 4-year limit)
ITAA97 s118.185: Partial exemption applies
14.46% of gain is taxable (first year of land ownership)
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies

properties.notes: Partial exemption (85.54%). Construction took 5 years, exceeding the 4-year rule. Land treated as main residence only from 1 Jan 2019 (4 years before move-in). First year of ownership (2018) is not covered = 14.46% taxable. Taxable gain after 50% discount: $13,340.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought vacant land in 2018 and built my home, but construction took 5 years due to delays. I finally moved in at the start of 2023. Now I'm selling. What's my CGT position?

scenarios.title: Subdivision - Separate Land Sale
scenarios.description: Karen owns a large block with her main residence. She subdivides and sells the vacant block separately from the dwelling. Because the vacant block is sold separately, it is NOT eligible for the main residence exemption, even though the dwelling block remains exempt.

scenario_info.name: Subdivision and Separate Land Sale

expected_result.notes: After 50% discount. Subdivided vacant land sold separately has NO MRE.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.165: Subdivided vacant land NOT exempt when sold separately
Vacant block is treated as separate CGT asset from subdivision date
Original cost base must be apportioned between lots
If sold together with dwelling, full MRE would apply to both lots
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies to vacant block

properties.notes: Dwelling block (Lot 1). If sold, full MRE would apply. Main residence entire ownership period.
NO main residence exemption. Vacant block sold separately from dwelling = no MRE under s118.165. Cost base allocated at 40% of original. Capital gain: $10,562. After 50% discount: $5,281.

scenarios.userQuery: I subdivided my large block and kept the house on one lot. I'm selling the vacant block separately. Do I get the main residence exemption on the vacant lot?

scenarios.title: Deceased Estate - COVID Extension
scenarios.description: Peter's mother passed away in March 2020. Due to COVID-19 restrictions on real estate activities, he was unable to sell the property within 2 years. The ATO provides automatic extensions for delays caused by COVID-19 government restrictions.

scenario_info.name: Deceased Estate with COVID Extension

expected_result.notes: COVID extension applies - sold 3.4 years after death but still qualifies for 2-year rule

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.195: 2-year disposal rule
PCG 2019/5: Automatic extension for qualifying circumstances
COVID-19 restrictions = Qualifying circumstance
More than 12 months of delay within first 2 years = Automatic extension
Peter did not need to apply for extension
If COVID extension didn't apply, partial exemption would calculate from date of death

properties.notes: Full exemption with COVID extension. Sold 3.4 years after death, but 22 months of COVID restrictions qualify for automatic extension under PCG 2019/5. 2-year rule effectively extended.

scenarios.userQuery: My mother passed away in March 2020 and left me her home. I couldn't sell during COVID lockdowns. I finally sold in August 2023. Is it still exempt under the 2-year rule?

scenarios.title: Small Business 15-Year Exemption
scenarios.description: David operates a photography studio from a commercial property he has owned for 16 years. He sells the property and qualifies for the small business 15-year exemption, which allows him to disregard the entire capital gain. He also contributes part of the proceeds to superannuation.

scenario_info.name: Small Business CGT Concessions - 15-Year Exemption

expected_result.notes: 15-year exemption - entire capital gain disregarded. Can contribute to super under CGT cap.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 Subdiv 152-B: 15-year exemption
Must own active asset for 15+ continuous years
Must be 55+ or retiring/permanently incapacitated
Entire capital gain exempt (not just reduced)
ITAA97 s292.100: CGT cap for super contributions
Exempt amount can be contributed to super under CGT cap
2024-25 lifetime CGT cap: $1,780,000

properties.notes: Full exemption under small business 15-year rule. Owned active asset for 16.9 years. David is 58 years old. Meets all conditions: active asset 15+ years, age 55+, small business entity. Gain of $309,700 fully exempt. Can contribute exempt amount to super under CGT cap.

scenarios.userQuery: I've run my photography studio from my commercial property for 16 years. I'm 58 and selling the property. Do I qualify for the small business CGT concessions?

scenarios.title: Investment Then Main Residence
scenarios.description: Amanda purchases an investment property and rents it out for 3 years. She then moves in and lives there as her main residence for 2 years before selling. The six-year absence rule does NOT apply because the property was an investment first. Only the period as main residence qualifies for exemption.

scenario_info.name: Investment Property Becomes Main Residence Then Sold

expected_result.notes: After 50% discount. Only lived-in period is exempt. Six-year rule does NOT apply.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.185: Partial main residence exemption
Six-year rule NOT applicable: Property was investment first, then main residence
Only actual residence period (39.98%) is exempt
Rental period (60.02%) is taxable
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies
Key distinction: If MR first then rental, six-year rule would apply

properties.notes: Partial exemption (39.98%). Investment first, then main residence = six-year rule does NOT apply. Only the 2-year residence period is exempt. Rental period (3 years / 60.02%) is taxable. Capital gain: $101,550. Taxable after discount: $30,475.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought an investment property and rented it for 3 years. Then I moved in and lived there for 2 years as my main residence. Now I'm selling. Can I use the six-year rule?

scenarios.title: Four Property Portfolio
scenarios.description: Victoria is selling her entire property portfolio in the 2024-25 financial year: her family home (main residence), a beach house (former main residence now rented), an investment unit (never lived in), and an inherited farm (from deceased parent). Strategic MRE nomination is critical to minimize total CGT.

scenario_info.name: Four Property Portfolio Optimization

expected_result.notes: After 50% discounts. Optimal strategy: Claim MRE on family home, use 2-year rule for farm.

applicable_rules: Property A: ITAA97 s118.110 - Full main residence exemption
Property B: ITAA97 s118.145 - Six-year rule exceeded (partial exemption)
Property B: ITAA97 s118.192 - First use to produce income
Property C: No exemption - pure investment property
Property D: ITAA97 s118.195 - Deceased estate 2-year rule
ITAA97 s115.25: 50% CGT discount applies to all taxable portions

properties.notes: Property A - Family Home. FULL MRE applies. Main residence entire ownership (8.8 years). Capital gain ~$680,000. Taxable: $0.
Property B - Beach House. PARTIAL MRE. Former main residence, rented 8.6 years (exceeds 6-year limit by 2.6 years). First use to produce income rule applies. Taxable gain after discount: $54,738.
Property C - Investment Unit. NO MRE. Pure investment from day one. Capital gain ~$75,000. Taxable after discount: $37,500.
Property D - Inherited Farm. FULL EXEMPTION under 2-year rule. Was father's main residence, sold within 2 years (2.3 years, within extension). Capital gain ~$55,000. Taxable: $0.

scenarios.userQuery: I'm selling my entire property portfolio this year: my family home, a beach house I used to live in but have rented for 8 years, an investment unit, and a farm I inherited from my father. What's my total CGT?

scenarios.title: Aged Care - Main Residence
scenarios.description: I moved into an aged care home 5 years ago. My old house has been sitting empty ever since - I never rented it out. I'm now selling it to pay for my care. Do I still get the main residence exemption even though I haven't lived there for years?

properties.notes: sold - Owner moved to aged care facility in 2020. House left vacant (not rented). No other property treated as main residence. Selling after 5+ years in aged care.

scenarios.userQuery: I moved into an aged care home 5 years ago. My old house has been sitting empty ever since - I never rented it out. I'm now selling it to pay for my care. Do I still get the main residence exemption even though I haven't lived there for years?

scenarios.description: I bought a holiday apartment in 2019 purely for Airbnb - I never lived in it. I'm selling now. Is it just treated like any other investment property for CGT?

properties.notes: sold - Owner continued living in property while Airbnb-ing spare room (20% of floor area) 2018-2025.

scenarios.userQuery: My property is held in a bare trust where I'm the sole beneficiary with absolute entitlement. The trustee is selling it but I've lived in it as my home since purchase. Do I get the main residence exemption even though I don't hold legal title?

properties.notes: sold - Husband and wife owned as joint tenants. Husband died Sept 2022. Wife became sole owner via right of survivorship. Property was main residence entire time for both owners.

scenarios.description: I inherited vacant land from my grandmother in 2020. She'd owned it since 2005 but never built on it. I built a house and moved in during 2022, and I've now sold. How is CGT calculated when I've added a building to inherited land and then lived in it?

properties.notes: sold - Inherited vacant land, beneficiary built home and lived in it. Complex CGT: Land inherited (cost base = MV at death), building added to cost base. Partial MRE from move-in date only.

sold - All 5 subdivided lots sold.

scenarios.title: Subdivision - Retain Dwelling, Sell Vacant
scenarios.description: I subdivided my property last year. I kept the lot with my house and sold the vacant block. I still live in my house. How is CGT calculated on the vacant block I sold?

properties.notes: sold - Subdivided 2024. Lot A (with dwelling) retained as main residence. Lot B (vacant) sold. Owner continues living on Lot A.

scenarios.userQuery: I subdivided my property last year. I kept the lot with my house and sold the vacant block. I still live in my house. How is CGT calculated on the vacant block I sold?

scenarios.title: Subdivision - Strata Title
scenarios.description: I converted my duplex to strata title in 2020. I live in one unit and rented out the other. I've now sold the rental unit. How do I calculate CGT for the strata unit?

properties.notes: sold - Duplex converted to strata title 2020. Owner lives in Unit A (main residence). Unit B rented then sold.

scenarios.userQuery: I converted my duplex to strata title in 2020. I live in one unit and rented out the other. I've now sold the rental unit. How do I calculate CGT for the strata unit?

scenarios.title: Tenants in Common - Unequal
scenarios.description: My sister and I bought an investment unit together as tenants in common. I own 70% and she owns 30%. We've sold it - how do we each calculate our CGT?

properties.notes: sold - Investment unit owned as tenants in common - Brother 70%, Sister 30%. Never main residence for either owner.

scenarios.userQuery: My sister and I bought an investment unit together as tenants in common. I own 70% and she owns 30%. We've sold it - how do we each calculate our CGT?

scenarios.title: Time Apportionment - Multiple Periods
scenarios.description: I moved in and out of my property several times over the years. I lived there 2008-2012, rented it 2012-2016, moved back 2016-2020, then rented again 2020-2025. How do I calculate the exempt and taxable portions?

properties.notes: sold - Multiple main residence and rental periods. MR: 2008-2012 (4 yrs), 2016-2020 (4 yrs). Rental: 2012-2016 (4 yrs), 2020-2025 (5 yrs).

scenarios.userQuery: I moved in and out of my property several times over the years. I lived there 2008-2012, rented it 2012-2016, moved back 2016-2020, then rented again 2020-2025. How do I calculate the exempt and taxable portions?

scenarios.title: Time Apportionment with Absence Rule
scenarios.description: I lived in my home for 5 years then rented it for 8 years. I know the 6-year rule gives me 6 years of exemption while absent. But I was away for 8 years. How do I calculate the partial exemption?

properties.notes: sold - Lived 2012-2017 (5 years), rented 2017-2025 (8 years).

scenarios.userQuery: I lived in my home for 5 years then rented it for 8 years. I know the 6-year rule gives me 6 years of exemption while absent. But I was away for 8 years. How do I calculate the partial exemption?

scenarios.title: Transfer to Family Trust
scenarios.description: I want to transfer my investment property to my family trust for asset protection. Will I have to pay CGT when I make the transfer?

properties.notes: Individual transferring investment property to family discretionary trust for asset protection purposes. Property has never been main residence.

scenarios.userQuery: I want to transfer my investment property to my family trust for asset protection. Will I have to pay CGT when I make the transfer?

scenarios.title: Trust Distribution to Beneficiary
scenarios.description: Our family trust owns an investment property. Instead of selling it, we want to distribute the property directly to my daughter who is a beneficiary. What are the CGT implications?

properties.notes: Family discretionary trust distributing investment property in-specie to adult beneficiary (daughter). Trust has held property since 2012.

scenarios.userQuery: Our family trust owns an investment property. Instead of selling it, we want to distribute the property directly to my daughter who is a beneficiary. What are the CGT implications?

scenarios.title: 2-Year Building Rule - Eligible
scenarios.description: I bought vacant land in March 2022, built a house, and moved in July 2023 - about 16 months after buying the land. I'm selling now. Can I get the main residence exemption from when I bought the land?

properties.address: Lot 5, 88 New Build Crescent, Kellyville NSW 2155
properties.notes: sold - Vacant land purchased, house built and moved in within 2 years.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought vacant land in March 2022, built a house, and moved in July 2023 - about 16 months after buying the land. I'm selling now. Can I get the main residence exemption from when I bought the land?

scenarios.title: 2-Year Building Rule - Exceeded
scenarios.description: I bought vacant land in 2018 but didn't start building until 2023 due to delays. I moved into the finished house in 2024 - over 5 years after buying the land. Have I lost the main residence exemption for the land period?

properties.address: Lot 12, 55 Delayed Build Road, Box Hill NSW 2765
properties.notes: sold - Vacant land purchased 2018, construction delayed, moved in 2024 (5.5 years after land purchase).

scenarios.userQuery: I bought vacant land in 2018 but didn't start building until 2023 due to delays. I moved into the finished house in 2024 - over 5 years after buying the land. Have I lost the main residence exemption for the land period?

scenarios.title: 2-Year Building Rule - Renovation
scenarios.description: I bought a property with an old house, demolished it, and built a new house. I moved in about 15 months after purchase. Does the 2-year building rule apply to knockdown rebuilds?

properties.notes: sold - Knockdown rebuild. Bought property with old house, demolished, built new.

scenarios.userQuery: I bought a property with an old house, demolished it, and built a new house. I moved in about 15 months after purchase. Does the 2-year building rule apply to knockdown rebuilds?
